title: CTRL0000061467 - Transcribed Interview of Robert Gabriel, (April 6, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:05
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a deposition of Robert Gabriel conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
Mr. Gabriel, thanks for joining us by Webex today.
If you could please just say
your full name and spell your last name for the record.
Would you please raise your right hand and the court reporter will
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under penalty of perjury that
the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but
We'll go over a few ground rules first before we get started to lay out how this will
This will be a staff-led deposition, and members of the committee may join and
ask questions, of course, if they so choose.
joined and I don't know that any will.
But as of now, I don't see that any have
with me today, to my right, is
but as I introduced to you before we got started, is
We also have several professional staff and the reporters who are on as well.
We'll follow the House deposition rules that we've provided to your counsel
previously, and under those rules you are, of course, permitted to have your attorneys
with you, and they are joining by Webex separately.
If I could ask your attorneys to please state and spell their names for the record,
and then understanding that you'll have objections to place on the record later before we
Paul Brothers, P-a-u-1, B-r-o-t-h-e-r-s, of Graves Garret LLC,
And Eddie Greim of Graves Garret as well.
So as you have now seen, Mr. Gabriel, there is an official reporter transcribing the
She and her colleagues, who are also on, are joining us by
For the benefit of the record, if you could just wait until we ask our questions
before you begin your answer, and we'll try to do the same and not ask our next question
The reporter can't record nonverbal responses like shaking or nodding your head,
so excuse us in advance if we ask you at some point to say yes or no or otherwise answer
And there might be times where you say a word or an acronym or someone's
name and we ask you to spell them, and that's just simply so the record is clear and we all
know who we're talking about or what we're talking about.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question isn't clear, just tell us or your attorneys will tell us and we'll do our best to
And if you don't know the answer to a question, just say so.
If at any point you need a break, whether for comfort or to talk to your attorneys,
go on mute so you can discuss in private if you need be.
We're happy to do that and accommodate it.
As a general matter, we can take breaks every hour, but if our goal is to be done,
say, around lunchtime, we're happy to keep going through.
We can all go off camera and
Throughout the deposition we'll direct your attention to exhibits that will be
There are two exceptions that I described to you and your counsel before we
But we'll flash them up on the screen so you can see them.
as much time or as little as you need to familiarize yourself with the document before you
These are exhibits that for the most part we shared with you
I'll try it now to see how the process works with exhibit 1.
And I say it and hope
Well, we can keep going on.
Exhibit 1, as you know from what we
provided yesterday, is just the subpoena.
the system works and you can see it, Mr. Gabriel.
So when we get it we'll show it to make sure
But otherwise, as we proceed, you may only refuse to answer a question to
preserve a privilege recognized by the select committee.
question based on a privilege, staff may either proceed with the deposition -- in other
words, move on -- or seek a ruling from the chairman at the time on the objection.
if the chairman overrules such an objection, you are required to answer.
If you refuse to answer a
At this time, I understand that your counsel would like to place on the record their
objections and make any opening remarks, so I'd ask them to do that now.
Mr. Gabriel has three objections that we are raising for the record to preserve in
the event Mr. Gabriel needs to assert those objections in the future, if the committee
were to require future document production or testimony from Mr. Gabriel.
However, we are not asserting these objections today to prevent Mr. Gabriel from
appearing, as he's here, or from testifying and answering the committee's questions
We're, again, stating these so that they are on the record and preserved for
The first objection is that the committee is not properly composed.
objects to the issuance of his subpoena because the committee is not properly
The resolution authorizing the select committee provides for the Speaker to
appoint 13 members to the committee and requires the Speaker to appoint 5 of these 13
members after consultation with the Minority Leader.
The Speaker failed to comply with these requirements.
First, the Speaker failed to appoint 13 members to the committee.
Second, none of the members of the committee were appointed in consultation
appointees and appointed all nine committee members on her own.
The Speaker rejected the Minority Leader's requested
The Speaker's failure to properly compose the committee invalidates all the
committee's activities, including the issuance of this subpoena.
this objection to the issuance and validity of his subpoena and does not waive this
objection by appearing and testifying today.
Mr. Gabriel's second objection is that the subpoena is not properly issued.
Mr. Gabriel objects to the issuance of his subpoena for deposition testimony because his
subpoena was not issued in compliance with the committee's resolution.
As I just noted, all nine members of the committee were appointed by the
None were appointed in consultation with the minority member.
The lack of appointments in consultation with the Minority Leader deprives the
title of vice chair rather than ranking member.
This is denoted by Representative Cheney holding the
The lack of a ranking member prevents the committee from properly ordering the
the ranking minority member when ordering the taking of depositions.
ranking member means by definition this consultation did not occur.
The rules of the committee require the chairman to consult with
Due to the lack of consultation, the subpoena for Mr. Gabriel's deposition was not
issuance and validity of his subpoena and does not waive this objection by appearing and
Again, Mr. Gabriel preserves this objection to the
Finally, Mr. Gabriel's appearance and testimony today does not waive objections
Mr. Gabriel raised in his document production.
As you're aware, Mr. Gabriel raised certain objections in his document production,
including that the issuance of his subpoena does not serve a legislative purpose and is not
pertinent to the inquiry assigned to the committee.
Mr. Gabriel preserves these objections, as well as all common law objections, and
does not waive them by appearing and testifying today.
Your objections are noted for the record.
And at this time, Mr. Gabriel, we will show you exhibit 1 just to see how the
And I'd ask my colleague to put it up on the screen.
Are you able to see that, Mr. Gabriel?
And do you recognize that as the subpoena to you by
So I'll just remind you before we get started, as we do all witnesses, that it is
unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
deposition is under oath, providing false information could result in criminal penalties, to
include for perjury and/or providing false statements.
Mr. Gabriel, how old are you?
And what is your highest level of education?
I graduated from NYU with my bachelor's degree.
Where are you currently occupied -- or where are you currently employed?
And prior to that, we understand that you worked at the White House.
I had worked at the White House for the 4 years.
self-employed, I worked at a corporation.
So when you worked at the White House that was in the Trump
I worked in the Trump administration for 4 years, and then I worked at a
I want to focus on the time frame of November of 2020 to January of 2021 when
you were at the White House.
What was your title at the time?
I was a special assistant to the President and director of the Office of the
And the Senior Advisor for Policy at that time was Stephen Miller?
And we focused on the November to January time frame.
you held that, those roles, though, in total?
At the end of the administration, I had that role -- oh, you mean like
I mean, I had the same role for the duration of the administration, but the
title had changed for, like, casual promotions.
So throughout those 4 years you reported directly to Mr. Miller?
Did anyone report to you by the end of your tenure, again, focusing on
November to January at the end of the administration?
Where was your office physically located?
I had desk space in the West Wing, yes.
Did you have another office in the EEOB or was that desk space in the West
Everyone in Stephen's office reported to him.
Was it in the West Wing?
Desk space in the West Wing was mine.
The last year, with COVID in the
spring and COVID at the end of the administration, I worked in, like, a vacant office in the
EEOB because it was kind of abandoned.
The desk space that you had, where was it physically within the West Wing?
Was it on the ground floor or was it the second floor?
We were on the second floor of the West Wing.
And in relation to Mr. Miller's office, where was your desk located, the desk
There was a little, like, suite before you go into his office and, like, another
adjoining office, and I was, like, in that common area.
And in the time frame we're talking about, November of 2020 to January
of 2021, would you regularly work in one location versus the other, that being the desk
space in the West Wing or your office in EEOB?
The overwhelming majority of my time I spent either working from home or
in the vacant space in the EEOB just because of COVID, and it was really prevalent at that
The West Wing I didn't really work too much in at that point.
As a general matter -- and, again, we'll focus on November of 2020 to
January of 2021-- what were your responsibilities in your role?
Same as always, which was assisting Stephen in his capacity as speechwriter
and a policy advisor to the President.
And when you say assisting, essentially just whatever help he needed you
But I just made sure, like,
the train was running on schedule generally for the whole tenure of my service.
And you mentioned speechwriting, which will be the focus really of today.
Throughout your tenure, the 4 years, was Mr. Miller overseeing the speechwriting team,
And who were the -- was there an official speechwriting office per se, or how
would you describe the group of people who worked on speeches?
official title or what was that?
I mean, we didn't have an office of speechwriting, so to speak, but Stephen's
office was comprised of the speechwriting office, and they worked in the EEOB.
Who were the -- of those people in the EEOB, we understand that Ross
Worthington and Vince Haley were the head of the speechwriting team.
Yes, I would say they were --
Yes, I would say that's an accurate characterization, yeah.
And that was true through November of 2020 through January of 2021?
Now, can you just describe for us just the process, as a general matter, for a
speech, how that would go from beginning to end, just an overview as you understood it
and from your perspective working for Mr. Miller?
So first you try and find out if there's a speech, when there's a speech.
generally make sure that it's tasked out, so make sure Vince and Ross are assigning a
to come up with a decent draft.
They work with whoever in the White House they need to,
Ross and Vince would review it, if they didn't write it themselves.
review it, Stephen looks at it.
back and forth however many times it needs to to be in a decent place for the Office of
And that office is generally responsible for all the paper
So we would send all of the draft remarks to the Staff Secretary's Office, who
would then circulate it, which means, like, provide it to all people who need to see it for
We work with them to reconcile the flags, the edits,
Like the speechwriters work with them.
It goes through the same process again.
They either send it back to staff
secretary or they make sure Stephen's good with it.
however many times until we're in a decent place, however long time allows.
at some point a draft is delivered for the President's review.
It goes back to staff secretary
And it can go back to staff secretary at some point if he has edits and stuff like
that, but it's just like a repeating process.
And the whole time I'm not writing, because I'm not a writer.
But I'm just making sure we're hitting, like, time cues, so like we're providing
So like making sure Stephen gets a draft, making
sure staff secretary gets a draft, making sure the President eventually gets a draft.
I'm just trying to keep the time at a decent pace.
And we'll just unpack a little bit of that, but thank you for the overview.
In terms of timing as a general matter, was there an amount of time you would
typically get in terms of a lead to put a speech through the process, or every one was
I would say generally it was scattered, it was unique for each circumstance.
So if you needed to do it in a few days, you could get it done in a few days.
If you had more lead time, you could work without more lead time.
was, you made sure the trains ran on time?
In terms of the President's input, the way you described it, it would be at the
end of the process, and if you had feedback, it could go back through the iterative process
to address any comments he had.
Is it -- was it typically the case that the President provided feedback after a fully
The President spoke publicly often, and Stephen was an advisor to him, so
they had an understanding of what each other wanted in remarks on a given topic.
So the President always had his ideas and thoughts incorporated, but he's not
going to be able to give, like, edits to a draft until he has the draft, which generally we
would try and get it through the staff sec review process before you provide the
So if you knew a speech was going to be made by the
President, it was not typical for the President to specifically say, "For this speech I want
It was just known about the topics how he had spoken about it in the
past and you'd work that into the -- it'd be worked into the draft?
And were there any rules of thumb that the President himself had for
speeches that the speechwriting team needed to be aware of and address as they did
I would say length was really the only thing, to keep it tight, short, sweet.
How about for Mr. Miller, was there anything in his oversight of the process,
involvement that he had, any rules of thumb particular to him as a speech went through
Just for the writers to get them as good of a draft as possible so he could
spend as little time as he could on it.
That's a good rule of thumb.
I'm sure Paul knows that well from Eddie.
So in terms of fact-checking speeches, to the extent facts were included in
speeches, was there a routinized process for that, particular people who would review
Generally, when a draft is provided to Staff Secretary's Office, staff secretary
would circulate it to the people who know the topic, as well as there was a fact-checking
operation in the communications office that I think received most of the speeches, and
The writers, of course, would have to like not put in things they couldn't
But Staff Secretary's Office was someone we -- the office we leaned on for that
kind of thing to make sure there was rigorous review of all remarks.
And when you talk about the speechwriting group itself, we understand
there were researchers employed by the group.
the fact-checkers on speeches, although not the only?
And would they serve that -- as one of
They would work on the remarks with
the writers to make sure that there is, like, there is actual substance to a speech before
it's sent through, like in the review process.
addressed in the staff sec review process, that's happened on occasion.
So whether that includes placeholders to be
But, yeah, the researchers would try and get the writers -- I think there were two
researchers or maybe one at that point in the administration.
and get the writers something to actually be able to write a decent speech.
When it came time for Mr. Miller to do his review of a speech, once the draft
was in shape enough for him to get hands on, would he review that electronically?
Would he do it in hard copy?
Or it depended on the circumstances?
But I would say the majority of time we
were on our desktops, like in the office.
And would he tend to do a red line?
In other words, if Mr. Miller was
reviewing, he'd go in and track changes himself for edits?
How would that work as a process matter?
I generally didn't take Stephen's edits on drafts unless it was, like, for the
prompter and, like, a document that he's already sent.
verbal or handwritten notes from him.
Or would he have you do
So I generally didn't take, like,
It was normally, like, sent on an email.
And during the time we're talking about, November to January, at the end of
the administration, was Mr. Miller coming into office -- into the office, to your knowledge,
He had his baby at some point after the election, so I think he had a little
But, again, I was working from home a lot of the time after the election, and I was
working in that office in the EEOB that was essentially abandoned because everyone else
was working from home or had left at that point.
So, like, I had the least interaction with him than I ever did at the end of the
administration just because we weren't working next to each other.
But, yeah, he had a baby at that time, so I think he had -- and there was
some issues with that or whatever.
But, yeah, I think it was -- we didn't see each other daily, that's for sure.
saw very little of each other at that point.
In terms of the President in his review of speeches, was there a format that
he liked to receive them to do his review and editing?
If he had edits, how would he -- would he handwrite those on the paper or
would he have someone take down edits listening to him?
Generally, he would handwrite his edits, yeah, to speeches.
So he had particular edits on speeches.
And who would take the handwritten edits and get them to the team to
Was there a person or a role that would handle that to make sure it got to
the people it needed to get to?
He had assistants sitting outside of his office.
The speechwriting office was in the EEOB, so no one is going to walk across the
street to deliver that to them.
But, yeah, the Office of the Staff Secretary received it always because we had a
would always make its way to the Office of the Staff Secretary or Stephen.
And really, as you can see, I'm just asking about the nuts and bolts, and you
make a good point about the EEOB and no one walking it over.
So how would the edits from the President get incorporated?
be -- would you scan -- would someone scan and send the edits to the speechwriting
Normally they would receive them over email.
like a scan or they would -- or they might like meet with the staff secretary in their office
In other words, they could walk from the EEOB to the West Wing and get it,
but no one is going to walk it to them is how it would work?
Is it right to say that there are speeches that are for official purposes of the
Now, I'll use language and you tell me right or wrong.
White House and then there could be campaign-related or political speeches the
Is that a fair way to characterize the difference between the two
So the process you've been describing, was that in any way
different if the speech was a political or campaign-related versus an official speech?
It would go through the same drafting, review, delivery process.
only thing different about it is you have to abide by the Hatch Act.
So counsel would always tell us, like, make sure you're using your personal
computer with your personal email to spend your time drafting the remarks.
And then when you're done drafting it and it's ready for Staff Secretary's Office,
you're going to use your -- it's going to go through an official White House process
because it's the President of the United States.
It doesn't matter if it's a political speech.
So it would eventually resume right when it hit Staff Secretary's Office into the,
And in terms of the review, given if it was a campaign or a political speech,
would that then also incorporate people from the campaign staff in the staff secretary
review, or how would the input, if anyone from the campaign, get incorporated into the
Yeah, I think Staff Secretary's Office did a good job of making sure the
who are the VIPs we want to acknowledge in this speech?"
And, to be honest, like the campaign didn't provide a lot
It was just like these speech acknowledgments, like, "Oh, my gosh,
But there wasn't much like -- if we were doing a rally in Pennsylvania, there wasn't
going to be much to get from outside folks.
And with regard to the speechwriting team, you talked about how you would
make sure that Vince and Ross assign a writer to any particular speech unless they were
taking the responsibility themselves to draft.
Were there any kind of guidelines for speeches that Ross and Vince would just
take the lead on and do themselves versus giving it to another writer?
how that would work internally on their team?
I think everyone had their wheelhouse, so, like, some people were better at
writing more emotional statements or ceremonious -- ceremonial statements.
would try and task it out to whoever would do best on that particular assignment.
But like, yeah, I would say, I don't know exactly how, but it was just who had the
bandwidth and who could do the best at that draft.
Was there someone in particular who tended to take the lead on rally
speeches for the President on the team, when you talk about wheelhouses and what
I'll just stop there and ask if my colleague
additional questions on just the process related.
I think if something comes to me, we can come back to it.
Yeah, I think generally Vince and Ross would do that.
So, Mr. Gabriel, on election night, November 3rd of 2020, where
Were you at home, were you at work, or somewhere else?
I was in the vacant office mostly in the EEOB, yeah.
And if we look at exhibit 2, it's -- I'll describe it.
But it's an email that Mr. -- that Ross Worthington sent on
election night at, you can see, at 7:02 p.m.
was sent to Derek Lyons and yourself, with Stephen Miller and Vince Haley copied.
Now, Derek Lyons at the time, was he the staff secretary?
And I'll tell you, if you look at the top just for context, there are going to be
times where I show you an exhibit where the time might look a little off.
this, though, the time is right on the November 3rd, that that's at the time in eastern
time, 7:02 p.m., when Mr. Worthington sent it.
And he says in the body, if we scroll down, "Attached.
underlined, and, "please do not forward and do not share.
And we can go and look at them, but it's three speeches that are attached labeled
speech A, speech B, and speech C, to address the situation of either the President winning
the election, losing the election, or it not being clear that night.
So do you remember that that's what the purpose of these speeches were in Ross
I don't recall receiving the email, just because you get so many emails, of
But, yeah, I mean, you would generally provide the candidate many options for
And for him to send it to Derek and I is understandable, considering Derek was the
staff secretary and I was -- I presume I was on it to be notified, like, "We have the drafts
So were you aware that these drafts were being written?
something that you had made sure was being taken care of in preparation for election
night, not the content but making sure Mr. Worthington and his team were drafting
were writing them, as they should have been considering it was election night.
I mean, I would say it's understood that an election night speech should be
But, yeah, I was probably aware that they
That's why we're asking if you remember.
Do you remember, as you sit there, whether any guidance was given to them
about what the content of these three speeches should be, about the messaging or
I don't recall, just because I was generally not giving counsel or involved in,
like, the substantive nature of the remarks.
So I don't know if they received messaging cues or points or whatever, but I think I
would have been aware that they were writing it because we would've needed something
Now, do you recall doing anything with these drafts that night to get them to
I don't recall doing anything with these, and I don't think I would have,
considering you're at the stage where you still have three drafts.
So I would think, sitting here, that it's like -- it's an action item for Derek,
considering he's the staff secretary, but I don't recall doing anything with these three
I don't know what I would've done.
And are you familiar with the fact that the President did give remarks early
in the morning on November 4th about the election?
Were you involved in any way just in the process of drafting those
remarks or getting those remarks to him for his review?
Well, again, I don't draft remarks, so, like, I never wrote speeches.
always just trying to make sure that things are actually, like, being worked on, things are
getting to Derek or to staff secretary, and things are making its way and we're making
progress and no one's forgetting about something.
Like you always have remarks scheduled.
So it's always just trying to make sure things are, like, moving along in the process.
That night specifically it's -- normally you want to make sure Stephen gets a draft,
speech is uploaded to the teleprompter.
processes that we had always followed.
You don't want one to fall through.
Eventually a draft is delivered to the President.
So I would think it's like all the normal
And understand it was only shorthand.
And for the rest of today, I
understand you're not actually drafting the document.
But thank you for the clarification.
But in terms of the process for the remarks the President ultimately gave on
November 4th, were you involved in that process?
Yes, making sure it's uploaded to the teleprompter, yeah.
Do you know who drafted his remarks for that address?
I don't recall who drafted like the final version, but as we see from the
exhibit, Ross certainly worked on the draft versions, yeah.
He certainly looked at the -- and we can look at those and compare them
against what the President actually said.
I guess what I'm asking is -- maybe it would be helpful.
Would you like to look at
the speeches, C, B, and A, just to see what those look like, and compare them against the
President's ultimate remarks or -- because, again, just trying to get to the question of, do
you know if it was Ross who actually drafted the remarks the President ended up giving or
I mean, it's not going to be anyone but Stephen, Vince, or Ross.
one else is going to be -- or the President himself.
So of the four people you just mentioned, and just trying to get particular on
the remarks the President actually gave, do you remember who at least took the pen
initially to draft the remarks he actually gave?
It's all like -- it would be in the White House email records.
election night speech, so it has to be like a Stephen, a Vince, or Ross.
Do you remember where Mr. Miller was on election night?
He was at the White House, yeah.
Was he in the West Wing or in the residence?
He was certainly in the West Wing because that's where his office and his
I don't know if he ever went up to the residence.
Again, I wasn't sitting in the West Wing that often then, so, like, I was more
disconnected than him -- with him -- than ever physically, just because I was, like, trying
to hide from COVID at that point.
So I don't know like -- yeah.
On November 3rd, on election night, did you, yourself, go to the West Wing
Yeah, probably to make sure that staff secretary had it and then later
certainly to make sure that the teleprompter was uploaded.
Did you have any personal interactions with the President that night, on
Yes, before he went out to speak.
Did you help him prepare to give his remarks, or do you know who did?
He would've done his review before he got to the -- like before he got to
where he was going to go speak.
So I don't know who reviewed with him.
During his remarks -- we can show them to you in exhibit 24.
And if, Paul and Eddie and Mr. Gabriel, if you would prefer to review this -- again,
as I said earlier, before we went on the record, this is one we added this morning.
is the text of the speech.
If you need a break to review it before we talk, let me know.
I think, just -- yeah, let's proceed with your -- based on the
question we may need a moment to review, but sitting here not knowing your question,
I'm not quite sure if we would need a moment to review.
But this is the transcript, Mr. Gabriel, and we'll look at what I believe is page 4, if
a paragraph that starts -- I won't read the whole paragraph -- but it starts, "So Florida was
And if we look -- if we go down to the second paragraph on page 4, it's
Carry on down to about the middle of the paragraph, I'm just going to read.
says, "This is a fraud on the American public.
This is an embarrassment to our country.
We were getting ready to win this election.
Frankly, we did win this election.
goal now is to ensure the integrity, for the good of the nation.
This is a major fraud on our nation."
Do you recall those words or words to that effect the President saying that night
That what his words that night?
That the election was a fraud and that, "Frankly, we did win this election."
But do you recall, since you were there, that the
President said words to this effect that night, November 4th?
Were you involved in any discussions with the President about
whether to say that he did win the election during these remarks?
Did you know at the time before he spoke that he was going to say the
I had no discussions with him about it.
I didn't have a relationship with him
Besides what he was saying publicly like beforehand, there was nothing else.
Do you remember whether the draft, the final speech that was loaded into
the teleprompter, had words to the effect that the election was a fraud on the public, or
is that something the President added himself as he was speaking?
You'd certainly be able to, like, compare it with the final.
have the final version of that speech.
But my recollection is that it was probably
Now, as you've just described your relationship with the President, I
understand that it's context, but I'll ask.
Between election night, November 3rd of 2020, and the inauguration of President
Biden on January 20th of 2021, did you ever have any conversations directly with the
President or were you present for a conversation with the President in which it was
discussed whether he won or lost the election?
So besides that night, like backstage or before he went to speak --
-- I'd only spoken to him once, on January 18th, I believe it was, which was
like his farewell video, which were, I believe, his last like remarks from the White House.
But I had no engagement or discussions directly with him.
He was giving speeches in the meantime, so, like, I'm still making sure the
So on occasion, before he starts the speech, I
Then I would generally leave when he would, like, finish, start making
But I never spoke to him directly, only like -- only January 18th.
And so that's -- were you ever present for a conversation or people speaking
to him, other than you, but you're present, where it was discussed with him in front of
you whether he won or lost the election, putting aside election night?
Nothing stands out to me sitting here.
But, like, again, if he's in the room
and I'm making sure that his teleprompter is set and he's ready to go, people could be
talking about it, but I'm not engaged in the conversation.
need to do in the room and then I'm leaving, so, yeah.
So I'm just -- I'm doing what I
Did anyone ever tell you that during the time period we're focused
on -- again, between November 3rd and January 20th -- that they told the President that
